channel.title: I think ubuntu is over rated
channel.description: just my opinion i have never gotten *Buntu to install on any of my computer(core 2 duo 1gb, pent4 256mb, amd sempron 512mb). i just flat out think PCLinux is better. ;D

Lol i started with gentoo before there was a nice graphical installer, and not knowing what i was getting into but its worked for me ever since

item.source: I think ubuntu is over rated

item.title: I think ubuntu is over rated
item.dc:creator: @nontitle nontitle
item.description:
@nontitle wrote:

scar_ownz:

It has never crashed on me ever,

Well of course, this is linux we’re talking about.

Anyways, I personally think Ubuntu is the best distribution. I like the fact that if i need something, i can go to a command line and type “apt-get install something” instead of looking all over the internet for it.

I used to use Redhat until it became enterprise, and it was the most annoying thing i had ever used. After that i used Fedora, and it’s the same thing. Then I heard about Ubuntu. I tried it and have been using it ever since. One thing about ubuntu that is cool, is the fact that you can install all the other variations and have them all at once.

Also, I only use DamnSmallLinux when I’m at someone else’s house.

Read full topic
item.source: I think ubuntu is over rated

item.title: I think ubuntu is over rated
item.dc:creator: @Fasga Fasga
item.description:
@Fasga wrote:

[quote=“Kmb, post:8, topic:118182”]Ubuntu was the first Linux distribution I installed, and I loved it. However, after using it for almost a year I wanted something new, maybe better, and decided to try Gentoo. It took me four days to install it (had to re-install five times, no GUI used during any of the installations), but it was worth it. You learn so much when you build everything by yourself, you can customize just about everything. I think anyone who has the patience and has used Linux for some time should give Gentoo a try.

Oh and Mopar, the packet Manager Gentoo uses is Portage, not emerge :P. However, the command “emerge” is used when calling Portage.

E: Some spelling.[/quote]
I’ve always wanted to try Gentoo, yet it never seems to successfully install on my computer.

Anyways, I too started on Ubuntu. The main reason I made the switch from Windows was just to try something new. Ubuntu stuck, and I used it for about 6 months. Next, I decided that I wanted something new again. Ubuntu worked fine, but it was a little on the slow side. That may have just been me, though. So, I browsed around, tried a few different distributions. I really didn’t like any of them until I tried Arch Linux. Arch is developed under KISS philosophy. None of those fancy GUIs to do everything for you, for the sake of simplicity.

I do think that Ubuntu is a great Linux distro, though. I just felt that it didn’t really fit my needs.

Read full topic
item.source: I think ubuntu is over rated

item.title: I think ubuntu is over rated
item.dc:creator: @kmb Kmb
item.description:
@kmb wrote:

Ubuntu was the first Linux distribution I installed, and I loved it. However, after using it for almost a year I wanted something new, maybe better, and decided to try Gentoo. It took me four days to install it (had to re-install five times, no GUI used during any of the installations), but it was worth it. You learn so much when you build everything by yourself, you can customize just about everything. I think anyone who has the patience and has used Linux for some time should give Gentoo a try.

Oh and Mopar, the packet Manager Gentoo uses is Portage, not emerge :P. However, the command “emerge” is used when calling Portage.

E: Some spelling.

Read full topic
item.source: I think ubuntu is over rated

item.title: I think ubuntu is over rated
item.dc:creator: @Ron Ron
item.description:
@Ron wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:3, topic:118182”]I would have to ask if you never succeeded on installing it once how can you give an honest opinion on it? That would be like me giving my opinion that horseback riding sucks even though I have never ridden a horse before. The saying “Don’t knock it until you’ve tried it” comes to mind.

I still believe that *ubuntu (personally I use kubuntu) is one of the best linux distributions out there, and it is what I use on all computers I have access to. I have tried many other OSs and so far I have always come back to kubuntu, I will write a short list of the ones I have personally tried.[/quote]

I was about to say the same.

The Un-Named:

Well, from what I can tell, *ubuntu is based on Debian, updated a bit more and Debian it’s self is used in servers, very stable, however, it seems the slogan “linux for humans” has maybe degraded it’s self a bit attracting the noobs, however the whole *ubuntu community is VERY helpful, even when it isn’t about *ubuntu!

Yeah they are very helpful! Everytime I have had a problem, they have always come through either in a post or in a personal message on the forums. They are very kind and very friendly toward new people trying Linux.

I agree to that Ubuntu is very stable. I have noticed very few bugs, and the ones that I have noticed and submitted were promptly fixed in the next update.

I don’t see how someone can find fault with anything without trying it first. This whole topic is based on a retarded statement. I’m not trying to initiate a ‘flame war’ just pointing out a prominent fact.

I have also tried my share of Operating Systems. I have tried Solaris, *buntu, SUSE, Slackware, and a few other Live CDs of Linux OSs. Like mwiebelhaus was saying, I have always ended up back on Ubuntu because they make it so easy to use, configure, and modify to my liking.

Read full topic
item.source: I think ubuntu is over rated

item.title: I think ubuntu is over rated
item.dc:creator: @mwiebelhaus mwiebelhaus
item.description:
@mwiebelhaus wrote:

scar_ownz:

while i see both of your opinions and since i don’t want to a flame war i just like PCLinux being it is just simple. It has never crashed on me ever, it boots fast, has a good selection of software and it just has the “cool touch” imo.

I used to use pclinuos but the video code cs really screwed up the lighting and there was just something about it i didn’t like. I think it was there was to much customization

Read full topic

item.source: I think ubuntu is over rated

item.title: I think ubuntu is over rated
item.dc:creator: @mwiebelhaus mwiebelhaus
item.description:
@mwiebelhaus wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:3, topic:118182”]I would have to ask if you never succeeded on installing it once how can you give an honest opinion on it? That would be like me giving my opinion that horseback riding sucks even though I have never ridden a horse before. The saying “Don’t knock it until you’ve tried it” comes to mind.

I still believe that *ubuntu (personally I use kubuntu) is one of the best linux distributions out there, and it is what I use on all computers I have access to. I have tried many other OSs and so far I have always come back to kubuntu, I will write a short list of the ones I have personally tried.

Sabayon (second best to *ubuntu from what I have tried)
DamnSmallLinux
Suse/OpenSuse
Fedora
Red Hat
Mandrake
Slackware
Debian
Knoppix
Solaris/OpenSolaris (not linux)
FreeBSD (not linux)

Out of my travels I have to say there is one thing that really makes or breaks a distribution, the package management system. Here I will put them in order of best to worst in my opinion:

  1. apt (debian)
  2. emerge (gentoo)
  3. suse’s whatever it is called
    …
  4. RPM (each distro seems to have a proprietary rpm system, which makes them incompatible and useless)[/quote]

True i started out with ubuntu and then i went and tried suselinux, fedora, pclinuxos, and i have always ended back with ubuntu or kubuntu.

The have huge support i usually get a reply in under 30 seconds on the forums, and they have alot of repositories

Read full topic
item.source: I think ubuntu is over rated

item.title: I think ubuntu is over rated
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

I would have to ask if you never succeeded on installing it once how can you give an honest opinion on it? That would be like me giving my opinion that horseback riding sucks even though I have never ridden a horse before. The saying “Don’t knock it until you’ve tried it” comes to mind.

I still believe that *ubuntu (personally I use kubuntu) is one of the best linux distributions out there, and it is what I use on all computers I have access to. I have tried many other OSs and so far I have always come back to kubuntu, I will write a short list of the ones I have personally tried.

Sabayon (second best to *ubuntu from what I have tried)
DamnSmallLinux
Suse/OpenSuse
Fedora
Red Hat
Mandrake
Slackware
Debian
Knoppix
Solaris/OpenSolaris (not linux)
FreeBSD (not linux)

Out of my travels I have to say there is one thing that really makes or breaks a distribution, the package management system. Here I will put them in order of best to worst in my opinion:

  1. apt (debian)
  2. emerge (gentoo)
  3. suse’s whatever it is called
    …
  4. RPM (each distro seems to have a proprietary rpm system, which makes them incompatible and useless)

Read full topic
